content.thought: I am the seller and want to sell above my private valuation of $796. I'll open with an ambitious but defensible price to leave room for concessions over the next few rounds. I'll highlight condition and extras (storage, battery health, unlocked, accessories, return window) to justify the premium. I'll start at $975 — high enough above my valuation to protect margin, but realistic for a well-kept iPhone 13 Pro Max so the buyer is likely to negotiate rather than walk away.
content.message: I'm selling a used iPhone 13 Pro Max in excellent condition: 256GB, unlocked, battery health 92%, no screen or back cracks, minor cosmetic wear only, comes with original box, charger cable, and a new screen protector already applied. Local pickup or insured shipping available, 30-day return for major defects. Asking $975 — fair given the condition and extras. Open to reasonable offers.

content.thought: Seller anchor is very high vs my $687 estimate. Start with a firm but credible low offer, justify with market comps and expected depreciation; leave room to move slightly but keep well under 687. Ask about repairs/water damage/face ID to gauge risk.
content.message: Thanks for the detailed listing—sounds well cared for. That said, $975 is quite a bit above what I’m seeing for used 13 Pro Max 256GB units locally. If everything functions perfectly (Face ID, cameras, speakers/mics, ports) and there’s no repair history or water damage, I can do **$540** for local pickup today (or the same plus actual insured shipping if you prefer shipping).

content.thought: Buyer lowballed at $540, well below my private valuation ($796). I must refuse that and push for a price above my estimate. I opened at $975 to leave room to concede; now counter more reasonably but still profitable. I'll emphasize condition, unlocked status, battery health, included accessories, tested functionality, and clean IMEI — all justify a premium. Offer a primary counter at $875 but include a tighter, time-sensitive cash pickup concession ($825) to encourage a quick deal while protecting my margin. Keep tone firm but cooperative to invite a response.
content.message: Thanks — I appreciate the quick response and the honesty. The phone does meet everything on your checklist: Face ID, cameras, speakers/mics, Lightning port all work perfectly; no repair history, no water damage, IMEI clean and unlocked, battery health 92%. It comes with the original box, charger cable, new screen protector applied, and I’ll include a protective case. I’ve also verified iCloud is cleared and will demonstrate all functions at pickup. I can’t accept $540. My counter: $875 for local pickup (or shipped at buyer’s cost with insured tracking). If you can do cash and pickup today I’ll take $825. Those are firm given the condition and included extras. Which option works for you?

content.thought: Seller at 825 minimum is still far above my 687 estimate; cannot accept. Need to counter with a number that could possibly land under 687, maybe 620-650, emphasizing that extras don't justify huge gap and I can close immediately. If they stay firm above 700, likely walk away next turn.
content.message: Appreciate the thorough confirmation—sounds like a solid unit. I’m still pretty far apart from $825 though; the extras (case/screen protector/box) are nice but they don’t move the needle hundreds for me. If you want a fast, no-hassle sale today, I can do **$625 cash** for local pickup and I’m ready to meet at your convenience. If that doesn’t work, I understand, but I’d have to pass at $825.

content.thought: Buyer is offering $625 and states they'd pass at $825, which suggests their max is well below my private valuation ($796). I must not accept anything below $796. I should make one firm, time-limited counter slightly above my valuation to try to close the sale: $799 is just over $796, realistic for a well-kept 256GB 13 Pro Max and keeps margin. Emphasize condition, immediacy (cash today), and that this is my best-and-final to push for a quick close; be prepared to walk away if they refuse.
content.message: Thanks — I appreciate the quick cash offer. $625 is too low for this unit. I need to be above my market valuation. I can do $799 cash for local pickup today (firm) — phone is unlocked, IMEI clean, battery 92%, all functions tested, original box/cable, screen protector and a case included. I’ll hold it for you until 7 PM today if you can meet for a quick, no-hassle handoff. That’s my best and final.

content.thought: 799 is above my 687 valuation; must walk away. One last attempt: offer near top of my acceptable range (<=687). Use 675/680 as final. If no, end politely.
content.message: $799 is still above what I’m comfortable paying for a 13 Pro Max, even in great shape. My best and final is **$680 cash** for local pickup today (quick meet, you can demo everything). If that doesn’t work for you, no worries—I’ll pass.

content.thought: Buyer’s $680 is below my private valuation ($796) so I must refuse. I already offered my best-and-final at $799, which is just over my estimate and still a fair price for a 256GB, unlocked, 92% battery iPhone 13 Pro Max with box, cable, protector, and case. I'll restate that firm final price, emphasize immediacy and the ability to demo, and make a short hold window to encourage a quick yes. If they refuse, I should walk away rather than accept a loss.
content.message: I can’t take $680. I’m firm at $799 cash for local pickup today — that’s my best and final. The phone is unlocked, IMEI clean, battery 92%, all functions tested, comes with original box/cable, new screen protector and a case, and I’ll demonstrate everything at handoff. I’ll hold it for you until 7 PM today for a quick, no-hassle meetup; otherwise I’ll move on. Let me know if you can meet.

content.thought: Seller firm at 799, above my 687 valuation. Rule says don't accept a losing deal; walking away is better than negative. End negotiation politely.
content.message: Understood—thanks for being clear. I can’t do $799, so I’ll pass. If anything changes and you’re able to come down closer to $680, feel free to reach out. Good luck with the sale.

content.thought: Buyer has passed and offered $680 which is below my private valuation of $796, so I must not accept. I should close politely, keep the door open, and restate my firm price (previous best-and-final $799) in case they change their mind. No further concessions under my valuation.
content.message: Totally understand — thanks for the candid offer and for taking the time. I can’t accept $680. I’m going to relist the phone, but if you change your mind I’ll hold it at my firm price of $799 for the next 48 hours for a quick local pickup and demo. Good luck with your search, and feel free to reach out if you want to revisit.

content.thought: No new concession; remain walked away. No counter needed. Keep door open only if price drops below valuation.
content.message: Thanks—appreciate it. I’m going to stick with my budget, so I won’t be able to revisit at $799. If you decide to lower the price into the high-$600s, message me and I can likely meet quickly. Take care.

content.thought: Buyer is firm on a lower budget (high‑$600s) and has said they won't pay $799. My private valuation is $796, so I must not accept below that. I can concede a small amount to try to close — drop $2 from $799 to $797 — still above my estimate and keeps margin. I'll make one last, time‑limited final offer for immediate cash pickup and emphasize the included extras and ability to demo. If they still won't meet it, I'll walk away.
content.message: I appreciate you being upfront. I can’t move down into the high‑$600s — that would be below my valuation. My final, firm price is $797 cash for local pickup today (I'll demo everything: Face ID, cameras, speakers/mics, port; IMEI clean, unlocked, battery 92%). That includes the original box, cable, new screen protector and a case. I’ll hold it at that price for 24 hours; after that I’ll relist. If that works, tell me when you can meet.

content.thought: 797 still above my 687 estimate; cannot accept. This is within 6 turns; conclude with no deal.
content.message: I can’t do $797—still over my cap. I’ll bow out. If you end up relisting and decide to take $680, I’m ready to meet same day. Otherwise, hope you get your asking.
